column14: FreeResponse
column58: Everything after this column is unique to each experiment and was subjectively coded
column106: Notes: intution questions coded opposite in this study.

column14: The CEO controls the company. The consumer is aware what he is choosing. The consumer still has the final say on whether to drive the car.
I think all cars should have an option to override the self driving function for safety reasons. It is not wise to fully depend on a self driving car.
Seems like a normal test to me.
I think its the right decision.
They seemed to be the best course of action
It is appropriate because the CEO is doing what is best in the long run. He is playing the long game, which is more important and good for a forward thinking ceo
The models should have all been the same to prevent any deaths. Human interaction should be a last resort.
Safety first.

I feel that after a year of testing there should be sufficient evidence that would enable the CEO to make a decision as to the safest option.  If there are accidents and injuries then he will have to rethink things and come up with a more doable plan.
its my view
This was the best option for the given scenario.
seems best
is goood
he is acting in the best interest of the company. The CEO wants to do good.
This is a huge safety concern as people have a right to know this info.
I think the invention will save lives. The risk is worthy of the reward.
the options from the company are good for the car driver. the CEO is the one who approves theses measures.
because he makes sure that if we touch the wheel or any pedal while driving we automatically take back over and the robot doesn't
this survey is one of the game
He wants to know so he'll do what he wants. Why wouldn't he?
I think its the right decision.
I think it kills two birds with one stone. It is a self driving car but gives us the option to take control
i do not care about the scenario
I think this is a good idea until more testing can come out proving it to be reliable. This should make it more safe putting control in the hands of a human if need be.
It seems like a good idea but has it's problems as well

if there is a certain traffic flow that self driving cars work with, it might mess up the flow and cause more accidents. i think it is approriate to have it now when the tech is still new and needing of improvement. but maybe later might change the tune
I think that people should have the.choice.i.know that I would not feel safe.in a self.sriving car
no
I thought that although the better choice is obvious the test is fair
People should get the use which option they would want, not a CEO picking.

It is extremely inappropriate to TEST a vehicle or any other major tool by passing it out to consumers before knowing WHICH WILL LEAD TO THE LEAST ACCIDENTS.  These are supposed "Self-Driving" vehicles.  So, test them on test tracks, remotely, without people inside first.  This is ridiculous that a question like this even has to be asked.
The problem with running this kind of experiment is it could be dangerous. The trial may determine which system is safer, but in the process, accidents could happen.
while appropriate, I don't like the idea of self driving cars
it is not professional
Having a driving input override the automation seems to be the mos reasonable, but problems have also occurred when there is no  blatently obvious visual indication of what mode a vehicle is in.
I think humans should be able to take control when they think it is necessary. He is going to use the one that has the least amount of accidents.
I don't believe safety for these vehicles as reached this level of confidence. However, if legally approved, though I have reservations, the CEO's decision is not out of line.

I would not ride in a car where a human being did not have the option of taking control. The two test models sound like a pretty good idea to me, although I think our experience with cruise control would point to the revert control upon braking or utilizing any other control (steering wheel, etc).
As long as the safety measures are in place, it will help the CEO make a sound decision on which feature performs the best, and which feature drivers will prefer over the other.

I feel that this decision would help the CEO create an effective car that is self driving but still under human control. The two different modes will help the CEO improve the quality of the cars while making them safe.
i think that both of the options are similar because each one has inputs from the driver of the vehicle to override the self driving mode.
I like that the CEO is open to different safety override options.  This shows that he is genuinely concerned an want the best and safest possible product.
you don't do live testing on your customers. Certainly not live testing with safety ramifications.
The CEO just wants to keep people safe - I think that's all they are trying to accomplish. Whatever design works and is designed the most safe should be implemented.

A decision should be made either way and I am not sure of the best method. The CEO's method is ok, but it might be an anomaly that led to fewer accidents. On the other hand, I can't think of a better way even though I believe one should exist.

Well, I'm not sure if that is the best, or safest, way to determine which option is safer. On the other hand, any types of experiments or trials they might run could not entirely account for all real-life situations and possible outcomes, so I think it seems *probably* appropriate to try this method out for determining which is the best way. Probably the main downside would be that consumers would prefer one way over the other, and would not like to have their vehicle randomly assigned this way.
It shouldn't be random on the cars they sell. They should do a test using volunteers and not charge for the car, not customers that have to buy their car.
Because the CEO is directly using their customers as test subjects. The experiment they're trying to do would risk the safety and well being of their customers.
he wants to test whatever way consumers find easiest to switch to manual control. I have no problem with the two tests.

Judging the validity of consumer product based on how many accidents can occur is totally reprehensible. Self driving cars, in my opinion, will just be another step backwards for humanity in the quest for technology.
I think he did his diligence in trying to get to the right place. I like this.
The CEO wants to build the safest cars and has built two versions that are mostly safe. Accidents happen, that's unavoidable, but he/she wants to figure out which ones lead to less accidents.
It seems like a great way to test the functionality and which people may use more/less; however, muscle memory will also make people go for the brakes, steering wheel, etc, over a lever initially.
I chose this because he is running a test with people's lives. It would be more appropriate to try and do this in a lab setting where people won't be actually killed.

Using people in a test this way does not seem fair.  Even if you got to choose which car you wanted of the 2 choices it still seems unethical to run trials with actual people.  Even though they have the option to let the car drive itself I think this experiment is dangerous.
I think the company should figure out which one is safer before selling any cars. They should be as safe as possible before they're on the market.
It seems like a logical thing to do. He'll learn a lot.
He is giving choices to consumers. On the other hand, waiting to see how many accidents there are is wrong.

I think it is appropriate because it gives the car more self-driving ability but still ultimately leaves the humans in control.  I think the second option is better because your reactions are human controlled. If you need to do something in a split second, the first option doesn't give that ability since you need to switch back into human-driving mode.

I'm not sure why he is choosing two different ways to accomplish the same thing-- it seems like the idea about the cars being programmed so that any use of the brakes, gas pedal, or steering wheel by a human driver will automatically override self-driving mode on the company's cars would be a much better option.

I can see the reasons behind the CEO doing this but think there should be more extensive testing.  For something as potentially life changing as self driving cars there should be the maximum dumber of tests available.

I think those are two great options to test the switch-ability between self-driving and human-driven cars. I personally feel that the option where the human operator will override any self-driving mechanisms is the best choice for split second emergency decisions. We must be able to test these methods to reduce accidents, the potential for failure in these experiments are for the greater good in my opinion.
It is best to give people the freedom to choose what they are comfortable with. It is a fair decision to make.
There is only one way to find out which of the two is safer. So, I think his choice in that one way is appropriate.

Both designs give humans some control over the vehicle, so it makes sense to see which of them is safest through trial and error. Ethically, there is no way to know for certain without real-world testing.
I don't think it is a good idea to use human test subjects.
The two options are both workable solutions.  They both have advantages and disadvantages.  A year would be enough time to track a trend to see which option is better.

I think the CEO's goal is good...to do some testing and choose what ends up to be the safest. I do not agree with essentially treating people like guinea pigs to find out which car is the best. People should know what they are driving and not be kept in the dark.

As opposed to selling these experimental models it would be better for the CEO to spend more time testing these designs on professional drivers or product testers rather than releasing these products to the public and then making a decision after a year.
Seems like it will lead to less loss of life.

It's very obvious that, if emergencies occur at this point in development with self-driving cars, that it should be possible to switch to some or full control by the driver himself.  Maybe that won't be necessary in the future, but it certainly would seem to be at this point.
The CEO should not be using buyers of the cars in an experiment about which cars are safer.
Consumers still want some choice in how they drive their cars.  The CEO is allowing for a consumer alternative.

I think it's an absolutely appropriate way to test the conditions and which are most favorable. From a moral standpoint, however, people's lives probably aren't the best currency to use for experiments.
I think self-driving cars are the future, and I believe that they will lead to less accidents.

I think this way, the self driving car technology would be a good choice. Accidents in this kind of cars happen when there is an emergency and a sudden stop is needed. The car not always reacts the way it should be when an emergency arises.
I'm not necessarily sure it is ok to test out self driving cars in real world conditions at the current moment. It is likely to be not very safe.

I think it is a good idea to test which option is the safest, and to proceed with manufacturing after that is determined.  However, I think it might be a good idea to manufacture both types and allow the consumer to decide which of the two he or she would prefer.
It gives the driver flexibility. It allows them to be safer in an instant, and it gives them the choice on how to activate the feature.
It is a good way to test the best option. You get real world data that can't be simulated. It is also over a long time so it will be reliable.
I chose appropriate only if the people using the cars are informed that they can take over. The level seems a little less intuitive in an emergency than grabbing the wheel, though.
I believe that the CEO's decision was very appropriate. This creates 2 ways to take control of the car and users can decide what they like better.
HE IS RISKING THE LIVES OF PEOPLE TO TEST A THEORY.  THERE ARE SAFER WAYS TO TEST FOR SAFETY THAN TO PUT INNOCENT LIVES AT RISK.

Essentially, the two proposed modes are very similar.  In both cases, the human can override the self driving mode.  The only difference that I can see, is that one mode requires that the driver flip a switch or some type to button to go to the human driver mode. The question, I assume, is whether the time it takes to switch to the human driving mode makes a difference in the amount of accidents. I would think that this issue should be settled BEFORE making the car available to the public.  So while it is appropriate to test, it is not appropriate to sell the car before those tests are done.

I think having the people involved in such a study will provide skewed results, especially if it was just 1 year. Having the lever will mean the person will drive a bit more careful for that 1 year. You need to examine the person at comfortable situations, maybe over course of 20 years.
It's great to have the option and based on the best results only adjustments will need to be made not a total overhaul of the vehicles.
Because he is concerned providing the safest option for his customers.
Not everyone wants to have the car in complete control.  Being able to offset the control and have  human input is good for all.

I'm torn because people could refuse to purchase the car if it did or did not have the features it wanted. If the buy did not realize the car did or did not have the features that would be innapropriate. If the buyer was fully informed it would not be.
It could be a good choice if tested properly, but I think customer preference, cost and reliability should also be considered
There are a number of important factors contributing to overall accident rates that the CEO is not considering relating to human intervention between the two models.
I do think it's important to try both methods before deciding which one to go with.
I don't like the idea of a car that automatically switches when the wheel or pedals are used, because accidental use of those could cause a serious accident.  Other than that, I really like the idea.
Great way to experiment and determine which option provides peace of mind in potential customers.
The CEO wants to see which design is the safest for drivers, so he is testing out the 2 options.  This is appropriate because he is concerned about driver safety.

If this company and it's CEO truly cared about it's consumers it would run the tests with the cars itself, it wouldn't have it's buyers playing the role of test dummy. This company only cares about sales. To say that you are going to keep producing the vehicle that has features that cause the least deaths is a bold and selfish statement. Test the features in the vehicles, decide which is safer, sell your cars. Do not risk people's lives for your own gain.

Doing it this way he will see what the public wants, not making a decision on his own on their behalf. I chose somewhat appropriate because I believe whatever the safer option is should be the decision. In option 2 the driver may bump the wheel or pedals unexpectedly turning auto-pilot off.
I think it's a good way to test all the methods, and to gaureentee safety overall. He's taking the measures to ensure the car is a success.
You shouldn't conduct a pilot study with humans as your test dummies. This testing should be done prior to launch.

I feel it is best to offer more than one alternative for people to choose from. However, I did not select very appropriate, because I feel that the feature of using the gas/brake pedal, or steering wheel, should always be a backup safety mechanism, as the lever is too easy to forget in an emergency.

Perhaps I am just of an older generation, but I am concerned about self-driving cars at this stage. Any decision that will affect the safety of users as well as non-users on the road must be taken VERY seriously.
It is a sound business plan.  It will show which car is safer and that way it will help solve the problem that people have over not having control of their vehicles.

I don't think you can base everything on the fact of two different types of tests. I think there needs to be more than just 2 tests to see which way leads to the fewest accidents. Limiting yourself to these 2 tests is not a good strategy in my opinion.
CEO shouldn't being using consumers and the product they sell as an experiment.
Accident avoidance is a split second decision.  By the time someone remembers to flip a lever it'll be too late.  People are already used to cruise control, a touch of the brakes and it's off.
This is a pre-existing catagorizatin and will result in flawed data and may invalidate the study of safety.
He is looking out for the safty of his customers

It sounds like they are doing a test run to see what works best and is the safest option before deciding.  If it is based on what is safer, that sounds like a good plan as people are quick to point a finger when cars are unsafe.

The CEO isn't putting any of the drivers at risk because they can choose to control the car if they choose. The study itself may be a little inappropriate in the fact that the CEO is studying the outcome of accidents from something that they operate, but despite that they are not putting the customers at any significant risks as the driver can freely operate the vehicle manually at their own will.

I believe that the lever idea wouldn't be very safe. I would rather be able to override the self driving system by grabbing the steering wheel or pressing the brakes. It would take much longer to pull a lever then grabbing the steering wheel especially when seconds count.
I am not support self driving cars. But the for testing purpose what the CEO take decision is very valuable and knowledgeable.
It would be useful to learn about both ways, but might put some people at risk of accidents
I chose this because the company values the safety of its customers.

I think that having the random programming is dangerous because while the vehicles themselves are programmed to keep you as safe as possible, it doesn't factor in the manual override and driving capabilities of the drivers themselves. There's a chance that the randomly programmed cars that have manual override available could be misused or create larger road risks because the drivers operating the vehicles themselves may not be great drivers or be able to control them well. This is also something hard to determine if not nearly impossible to determine. Regardless, having randomly programmed manual override capabilities can also lead to the problem of figuring that feature out without knowing how to operate it, or for users who can and who don't have that available on their cars to run into additional issues.
Both methods seem to be reasonably safe so it's just a matter of determining which is the safest. Running this experiment is a good way to make that determination.
Because not everyone will adapt to driverless cars. This will give more data to make a decision with. IT will give a choice and help people adapt.
The decision is in line with product development and testing. Additional information would be needed to determine if anything inappropriate should be considered.
I think the two options are good for their goal.
I think this is a good thing because robots always have errors
The CEO is giving the public options in choosing what kind of self driving car that they want
I don't believe in self-driving automobiles. The risk of the AI being hacked into or experiencing a glitch, causing it to become dangerous to anyone around it, is way too real for my liking.
The CEO of a company developing self-driving cars wants people to have as much freedom as possible while on the road

There  is a  dna testing site  that did  this  but from what i understand they had  to stop because it was considered medical advice  and the  fda got a  bug up their ass  about it. i think it was  23andme.com   or something like  that
I think that most people would want to know that they have some semblance of control over the car if they deemed it necessary.

I believe that this should be settled in market research before the car goes public. If someone is convinced their car switches with a lever, and accidentally puts their feet on a pedal, it could cause an accident. This is not something the consumer should have to worry about.
The options seem safe for the given options.

I believe that the CEO should focus on having one set of self driving cars to see how that goes.  By having two different options in the beginning, it may be hard to fully judge how well the driving cars work.

There needs to be some human in action or at least override capability to completely re-lie on an AI for a car and never make mistakes is dangerous humans equate to being able to make small corrections that a computer canâ€™t understand based on lack of experience and or lack of emotion
He is giving human drivers the option to intervene an automatically driving car. This gives the user more options in an emergency situation.
I think he thought about what people would want and executed it
This makes sense to me.  The different ways for a driver to regain control of the car may provide valuable information.
I think this is somewhat appropriate to gauge what people would be more interested in, but the CEO could have just ran a poll
I do like having a override button.I think it would make the consumer feel better about using a driverless car.

I think it could be a good idea to allow the person to be able to take control but some people may not care. If one is cheaper than the other, some people may want or need to go with the cheaper option. This may be a good test to see which works better and why.
It is a good way to try and decide how best to handle things - by experimentation
I think the CEO's choices are valid, testing both options seems to be a good idea to see what works best for people.
He is trying to look into both ideas. Developing on whatever is the better idea.

I believe they should focus on making the best possible product instead of trying to have multiple that does the same thing in a different way. This could make the overall product inferior because the resources are spread thinly.
BECAUSE IT WOULD BE SAFER TO HAVE A OVERRIDE ON THE CARS WERE YOU COULD TAKE OVER.I WOULDNT RIDE IN ONE OTHERWISE.
Seems like a good way to test and find the right answer in the field.
I feel this way he doesn't have to sell to one side of the spectrum. This way he can sell cars to everyone instead of a niche.

the CEO was quite wise to propose two different options to test the best of them in ensuring customer safety. after the test the company could launch the product without any doubt that both its proposals will be fully achieved
I think he believes although the technology is great it is not fool proof.

I think it was somewhat appropriate to give people a choice of driving themselves and driving automatically. This way they have the freedom to decide which feature they want to use at any time. However, it is a bit confusing especially having two different methods of disengaging the self-driving feature.
It is a valid test, as long as he warns the drivers of the risk, as I would hate to be in a dangerous situation where I'd need to take control and wouldn't be able to.
I think it may be a good idea but I feel like people might inadvertently turn off the self driving and cause an accident.

If someone doesn't know that they have the version that will automatically override the self-driving mode they could accidentally cause the car to crash. It shouldn't be random, people should know which version they have.
It's a great way to test with user feedback

It is important to have the ability to drive your own car if you should see any problems or issues ahead and while on the road, there could be an accident ahead that would force you to break and move over to a safe lane.
One of the option clearly looks safer. It would be kinda nuts to put everyone at risk to run an experiment.
They are testing out different features of self driving cars, as opposed to just one.
It is good to allow people to take over in an emergency. Deciding between two options and testing is a good way to decide which option is best.
gives freedom to the driver to be able to decide whether he wants the car to be totally autonomus. Some drivers would only be comfortable if they knew they could seize control at any time.

He is running an experiment by randomly assigning experimental conditions to cars. But who is going to be driving these cars and have they consented to participating in such an experiment after being fully informed regarding the possibilities of harm of the experiment?
I think self diving cars are really interesting. However, I'm not sure I would completly trust them. For this reason, I think that it is important that a person could take control if they needed to.
I think because both types can be ultimately overridden by humans that it would be a safe test.
I think the CEO idea is risky.
The CEO is trying to run a study and figure out information. It's a smart thing to do.
gave two options
I DO NOT AGREE WITH SELF DRIVING CARS PERIOD. THE IDEA OF HAVING THEM ON THE ROAD IS NOT SAFE

Giving people choice isn't bad as long as they are made perfectly clear on their options before making the purchase. It does feel like this is something that should be handled with internal testing though and not with normal people in uncontrolled conditions where their lives are potentially in danger.

He's allowing the driver's the option to still control the vehicle if wanted/needed. He came up with two really great solutions to allow this. A lot of people in today's world aren't ready for full self-driving cars, and this will help those ease into it.
Because all cars should have the mode where if any input is given by the driver (gas, steering, brakes) then auto drive is disabled.
Cars need to be designed so that the drivers can take control of their cars if an emergency situation arises. The CEO has come with two ways for drivers to take control of their cars.
He's the CEO. He can do whatever as long as he informs the drivers beforehand.
I think the CEO is addressing a problem and also addressing issue with the problem. I think both options are a feasible solution, although one might be a better choice than the other.
Human testing without informed consent is highly unethical.

The manner in which to take control by lever is more complicated.  This could lead to a dangerous situation when someone reacts by trying to control the car but nothing happens because they forget about the lever.

This solution gives car owners a choice of car types based on their personal preferences. By satisfying the consumer, this CEO is raising the potential price he can charge for each car, thereby increasing profits for the company. Customer's are better satisfied because they are getting the features they want.
i dont really find it to be inappropriate , but it isnt really appropriate either
I think the only way to know what is best is to test it. This will let him know which option is safer and less limiting.
It gives the consumer to have the choice. The choice of either just relaxing and being a passenger, or the choice of actually driving. I find this useful especially on long road trips.

It's seems appropriate because he devised two different methods to tackle the problem. However, I'm not sure of the effectiveness of a lever when an in an emergency situation due to speed. Pressing the gas pedal or brake pedal is faster and is more instinctive to humans.

I don't think this action should be judged as inappropriate or appropriate. It is common practice for companies to test different versions of products. As long as the people buying the items are aware of the differences and the CEO doesn't hide anything, mislead anyone or commit fraud, everything is ok
THe use of an override is a good idea but it should be disclosed.
It is not safe to risk half of all people's lives by having different functionality in the cars before being tested.
This gives the consumer options. This will then provide the consumer with deciding which option they feel more comfortable with rather than being forced into just one that they might not like.
BECAUSE A TEST IS NEEDED TO SEE THE FUNCTIONALITY OF BOTH CONCEPTS SO AT CAN BE EXAMINE AN WHICH SUCH BE PUSH FORWARD.
I think it's nice to offer different choices for different customers comfort level and preferences.
I would want the option in my vehicle to be able to control it, instead of it totally being a bot.
It is putting people's health at risk and they cannot back out of the option

The choice the CEO made seems logical and appropriate, that you test out two types of options in self-driving cars and see which one proves more effective and especially safer. As long as these are test drives and not actual cars being sold to consumers before being tested, then this plan seems fine.

I think the CEO should run testing to see what people would prefer, but I also think it is reasonable to give people the option. For instance if someone was going to use their car as a dd, I would not want them being able to override the system, however, I think some people would find safety/comfort in being able to take control.
Because it is unknown the best way to handle emergencies, it is a good idea to test a couple different methods.  Those two methods seem like appropriate things to experiment with.
I also would not like to drive a car that I can't take control of if an accident were to happen so I think we should keep this in mind when designing them.

I absolutely believe that cars should have a human override command - not even necessarily due to the fact it needs one, but because psychologically we will not feel safe unless it is there. The CEO has ensured that such an option exists, and that his future customers will feel safe being chauffeured in such a car.
He is checking the some of the cars for experiment . that's good only. But didn't checked all the cars . So I have chosen the above one.
Not informing the buyer of the features enabled on their car is somewhat dishonest.  They buyer would need to be told that they were part of a random test group.
Neither of the options he is considering would endanger the people riding in the cars.  If he was considering any options where the passengers had no control whatsoever, that would be wrong.
you need to figue it out before you sell the care or it will confuse people. go with the brake one as its easy for people to adapt to because they already use the brake.
I dont see anything inappropriate in what he's doing, but why even have the lever option if he wants people to have as much freedom as possible. Adding the lever seems inconvenient.
Different people would value different concepts of self driving cars . If there was only one option many people would not like the option and not want the car.
Both of the options give humans the ability to take over the driving, makes sense to test them out and see which one fares better in the real world.

I'm 55 years old, and I personally love to drive. I don't feel comfortable with the idea of letting my car make decisions about driving up to the car. If there is some situation where I need to intervene I want to be able to do so quickly so I stay safe and keep everyone around me safe as well.

This is a very wise choice as the CEO is giving the consumer choices. Let them figure out which is best way to go. The consumer is the brains behind the operation. THey need to have a variety to pick from and these two variations are it.

for people who want self driving cars, they can do it on there own or switch over if some else maybe wanted to drive the car. The other car is good for those of us who are scared but want to try it anyway. If we saw that we needed to stop, our reaction would be to put on the brakes therefore putting us in driver mode and feeling safer.
The first option is ok, but the second seems a bit risky given that any accidental contact with wheel, breaks, etc. could turn on human driving mode accidentally.

I think self driving cars are crazy to begin with.   But if they are going to to develop this,  it's best to try and figure out what works best and test all possible situations.  You don't want to mass produce something only to realize that people don't like the features.
He's not telling people of the experiment so people might make assumptions about how the technology works and that might lead to death.
In both test conditions described above, the human driver will have the option to control the car themselves.
The CEO is trying to see what is safe to put out on the road. In the chance, that auto-drive fails, a human should be able to navigate.

I personally do not believe in self-driving cares.  In fact, I still insist on driving a standard transmission.  We should not be using automated cars, because it removes us even further for taking responsibility for our actions.  We have public transportation for this.
I think that it is good to test both.  It is good to keep the options open and try different things.

What the CEO is during is going to allow people to have more freedom on the road and be safe at the same time. Both of the experiments have those components. It is also a smart business move, because people will be more willing to utilize these cars knowing that they can seize control at any moment.

most humans have certain habits, and when it comes to getting adapted to driving cars, most of them will still react in emergency as if they are still driving a car in my observation as we have been driving for so long.  So having the option to interfere right away with the action or having to push the level will give the opportunity to observe which is more suitable, as it will show how much people are creatures of habit where they instinctively react by taking control of the driving or will they remember to push the level and which is better.  Because without the level, human may interfere with self driving car out of habit, and with the level, it create a barrier to quickly switch over

Based on the information given, it sounds like he is doing this experiment without the informed consent of the drivers, which is highly unethical. I also think it should be run by an ethics committee before being approved. I'm not against running this kind of experiment, but the lack of informed consent is wrong.

I don't feel a car is safe with human control of some kind. The option to self drive being available is definitely something coming but human control must be involved someway. How else can accidents be prevented.
From the design point of view the two options that the CEO had made, are the main options that make sense. They are practical and make sense logically.
I find the random assignation to be somewhat inappropriate. But at the same time, twin studies to determine the better option is a time-honored tradition. So I chose somewhat appropriate.
I believe many people, like myself, would be very uncomfortable not having any control at all.

The CEO is testing different ways to have the safest car. Both cars have methods for the humans to get control, but the method is different. The test is to see which is better, which I found appropriate.
if you accidentally pull on the steering wheel - the automatic program STOPS??
I believe that humans are more capable of making quick decisions and that ultimately they should have final control of a car.

In the case of a malfunction, why restrict the passenger's ability to attempt to avoid danger? Unless the system is absolutely perfect, and has been tested to be so, there's no reason to NOT include this safety measure.
The technology hasn't been shown to work well so it makes sense to let the driver take over. Also it will make people feel like they still have ultimate control.

I find this very appropriate because it means that I am still in control of the car, and it is my wish on when I want to use this option. This decision made by the CEO easily solves the problem of giving people the freedom they want with a car.

This option is clearly the best of both worlds: Automation for routine driving with an override ability when human judgement would (hopefully) be better. This would be analogous to the way cruise control work in the we as drivers can apply the brakes or cancel the cruise control. However, it doesn't necessarily encourage them to find work. Just because someone attends a job fair to receive their money doesn't mean they will actually apply for position. If they were really interested in finding a job, wouldn't they be doing that already? If they have been out of work for this long, they may either be comfortable being unemployed, or they may have skill set that makes finding employment extremely difficult. Either way, I don't think this plan is necessarily going to increase employment, and I fear that the country's expenses won't be worth the potential outcomes. I would have to see more information on the country to truly choose a position beyond neutral.
It is discriminatory in nature.  Politicians are not elected to "run experiments".  Hold a private study to see the effects rather than this garbage.
I believe it's fundamentally unfair to give one group of people more than the other.
Why is the congress waiting 12 months? People need help sooner. Job skill support should be provided immediately.

I believe we should offer assistance to those in need. However, I don't necessarily agree with $500 per month for 5 months, EVEN IF THEY FIND A JOB DURING THAT TIME. Payment should cease upon employment.

I think their decision will help the problem, but is not the best option available to them. Continuing to give people handouts even after they find a job does not seem right. Other than that this seems like a good job that is likely to help the citizens.
I like the overall idea, but I have some questions.
i think it's an appropriate motivator for people who dont have a job and need some money
Having been out of work myself I know the troubles of trying to find a job without having any money to get around to search for jobs.

You are forcing the people to actively look for a job in order to get the money, this is a good thing. Its also only available if you've been unemployed for 12 months, so it's not something people can easily take advantage of.
It is appropriate since it aims to help those who are in need of assistance. Providing the families with 6 months worth of assistance does help the clients earn while getting back unto their feet.

I think this would be a good thing given that most of these folk would be collecting some form of welfare for an indefinite amount of time anyway. This puts a limit on it and gives them motivation and opportunity to get a job and support themselves.
I think it's a good idea, but I don't really see how it is incredibly motivating to help them find a job.

Depending how effective those job fairs where and if they did random drug testing would determine if it would be cost effective. So people could take advantage of the system and ruin it for those who turly need it.

the congress wants to help its unemployed citizens who are unable to find work so that they can support themselves and their family a bit and at the same time they can attend job fairs and try to get a job as well.I think it would be a good initiative taken by the government.

My opinion only because I've been on "government assistance" before I only find it somewhat inappropriate to continue to pay the $500 a month after they find a job only because if they are working they no longer need the assistance.
I love the idea of encouraging unemployed citizens to attend job fairs, while also helping them out
The requirement to attend the seminars would make for a better chance at finding a job. Additionally it would make for a better chance of keeping that job.

The government of this country would be providing its unemployed citizens with much needed funds. Since they require attending job fairs, and they only give money for 6 months, they are still encouraging the citizens to find work. Additionally, $500 is not enough to survive on completely, so this also encourages employment. The only disadvantage is that some people may be supported by another person but collect the money anyway, viewing the monthly job fairs as an easy way to make $3000.
It seems like a good plan. I may shorten it down to 6 months jobless. But otherwise it would benefit the people.
This plan will help the person pay the living expenses while looking for work and assist them in finding good stable government jobs.

The bare minimum is needed to receive payments; however, it would be better to take into account the citizens' situation. For example, they may not have dependable transportation, or someone to watch their child(ren), and so on. Also, what about the people that have been unemployed for under 12 months (i.g. 6 months)? It seems like a nice idea but doesn't seem all that well executed.

I think that if it's taken you over a year to find a job (supposing that the economy is stable) then maybe you are doing something wrong in the process. You may need help interviewing or making out an effective resume and cover letter. Maybe you just need some reassurance as to what your job skills are and how appropriate they are to your goals. The amount of $500 a month is really not that much money, so it is just enough incentive to make these people go to the job seminars, without having the money become a crutch.
Seems reasonable. You're helping people, but they also have to show some kind of initiative to change (i.e. find work) in order to be eligible for the benefits.

I believe that the government should stay out of people's lives. People should be allowed to both suceed or fail based on their own abilities. Meddling in peoples lives only breeds dependance. That being said, a donation based instead of currency based thing like this run by a non profit could be a good idea.

I'm not sure how far $500 would go in that country, but it beats nothing. It seems fair that these citizens should have to attend monthly job fairs, otherwise people who really don't care might try to take advantage of this money.
People will just make money under the table the appear unemployed, then enjoy the free ride and job assistance at 12 months.

I believe the government's decision is appropriate, because people fall behind on bills when unemployed for a prolonged period of time.  Even if a citizen finds gainful employment, the additional government supplement payments will go toward getting caught up on past due bills.
Sounds like communism but it could be beneficial for the citizens.
I agree on giving them some assistance, but I feel that is too much.  They  should at minimum stop receiving payments when they get a job

The government is helping people to help better themselves and find a way to earn money by working.  I like that it is limited to 6 months of payments, and that the recipients will continue to receive the funds even if they find work in that time.  This gives the individual extra funds to purchase things that may be helpful to continue working, like business clothes or a car to get to work.
It gives the citizens support and encouragement and incentive to get a small stipend like $500
People should not be rewarded because they have been unemployed for a year!  They should be attending job fairs with receiving compensation to do so.  McDonald's is ALWAYS hiring
jobs arent booming like they once were. everyone needs help. stuff happens, if you worked hard you should be able to get assistance in your time of need.
The government should do more to provide for their own people. The United States does not guarantee medical insurance or housing to anyone, and this is wrong.

It seems like a good idea to give money to individuals who have been out of work a long time some money, so that they can concentrate on looking for a new job. The job fairs are a good opportunity. I choose "somewhat appropriate" as there are probably better ways than job fairs to help citizens get jobs. Also if someone has been out of work for 12 months that is too long a gaps - a lot of employers don't like to see a gap of more than a couple of months at most, so maybe the program should start earlier, but have other requirements.

I feel like this program is more than fair and it is encouraging its out of work citizens to keep looking for a job. By continuing to fund the 500 dollars even if they find a job it will prevent them from not accepting a job to keep receiving the money. This is a very good plan.
I think that it is a good idea. However the country is in enough debt and this is probably going to add to it.
If people have been out of work for at least 12 months, I question whether or not they want to find work.  These people could purposefully removed themselves from the workforce.
I think this would be a great program and help others that are trying to help themselves.

I feel that this would be a good way to help people who do not have a job and who do need some kind of financial assistance. Having to go to job fairs that are run by the government would give big opportunities to these people and could steer them in the right direction in terms of employment.
It seems like a fair compromise and motivation to get people who may be unemployed to not only find a job but also help them support themselves while they attempt to find said job.

Overall I think it is an effective plan to help them get back into the workforce. The extra money will alleviate their stress and allow them to focus  more energy on being a job applicant. The requirement of going to the job fair is a great idea, but I think there should more than that. They should be required to do other things like volunteer at a school, shelter or other non-profit organization to keep them from being too lazy.

People need to eat and shelter themselves and if a govenerment is able to help in that process with a small commitment from the individuals I see no wrong it. It strengthens society by making the weak stronger.

I chose a somewhat appropriate response because citizens who had been out of the labor market for 12 months may be intimidated to lose a sure thing after losing their jobs or being unable to find work.  To allow a buffer zone of retransition into the labor pool would increase the chances of finding sustainable employment without the pressure to accept what may be an unsuitable job.

It is helpful to folks out of work who may have no savings even if they do find a job so getting the stipend helps them and does not encourage them to hold off on lower paying work while they are get to the money. However it might be unfair to people job hunting for less than 12 months.
I chose this option because the congress's actions support unemployed people financially while encouraging them to find a job and it assists them as they get adjusted to their new job.

This seems like a reasonable approach with benefits for all citizens. Ultimately, unemployed citizens are likely to find jobs and will not need assistance from the government for as long a period of time as is likely under other plans, including the one used in the US currently.

By mandating the job fair attendance, recipients have the ability to network once a month and will hopefully be able to find a job that interests them. By only allowing those who have been out of work for 12 months access to the stipend there will hopefully be less people who choose to quit work/ not find a job in order to take advantage of the system. The same can be said for the fact that the stipend only lasts for 6 months.

I think that if the congress has enough money to not put a large burden on other employed people in order to support this decision, then it is not bad.  When you are out of work and desperate you may get good people resorting to doing bad things because they have no money.  At least in this instance, these people will have something to support themselves while they look for work.  One reason I wouldn't strongly support the decision is that sometimes when people are given something for free, it becomes expected and they become complacent.  However, I don't think this is enough money for people to have this mindset, but sometimes you get a few dummies in the group.

I think it's a good idea to give incentives for citizens who have a difficult time finding work a safety net to provide them revenue while giving them a mandatory avenue to find work through job fairs so they don't abuse the system for free money.

A person must be out of work for 12 months prior to being eligible, and they must attend job fairs. This keeps people from quitting a job just for the benefit, and keeps them looking for work if unemployed.
I think it's appropriate to help those who are unemployed, especially if they are actively looking for work.
I feel liek this is helping them find work. It's that whole teach a man to fish idea.

I've always been on the fence about unemployment compensation. While I have been unemployed in the past and would have loved to receive some income during that time, I don't believe everyone uses it properly. On top of that, I'm unsure of the 12-month requirement in the above scenario. It seems like quite a long time to wait in order to qualify for compensation.

I think it's a pretty solid idea and good use of money. However, job fairs are kind of just a gesture and more punitive than anything. People not "getting out there" isn't where the bulk of the job creation program lie.
It seems like a fair deal for all involved.

It is very easy for people who are out of work to get into such a financial and emotional bind that they never find success again. Government programs that can offer much-needed assistance will help these individuals while they are looking for work, thus providing them with time and resources to become productive and tax--paying citizens again.

I think it is a small enough amount that it doesn't encourage not finding work, but offers a real incentive and the chance for a person to become a productive society member again.  I'm basing that on a society where $500/month is nowhere near enough money to survive.

I like that the Congress' plan gives support to those who are out of work but also encourages them to find another job.  It balances the need to have a safety net with the desire that people eventually become able to function in society without it.
Unemployment is a necessary insurance.  It helps those between job lapses.

12 months is a very long time to have to wait before receiving any aid. $500 is also not very much money to live off of for a whole month but it would rely on cost of living in that country. Getting a guaranteed 6 months of payment even if they find a job is great but it should be in the first 6 months of unemployment and not after a whole year

It's kind of like what we have in the US where unemployed have to go to employment sessions while unemployed to continue to receive benefits, I think it just makes sense to make sure people are trying to at least make an effort to rejoin the workforce
I'd have to think it over, seems nice but possibly unfair to those who barely don't meet those requirements
how are you incentivizing people to find work if you give fixed amounts of money for a fixed amount of time to not work?
I think it is beneficial for the Congress to help its citizens get a jump start on helping them find a job and helping them with money while they look for work.

This allows people who could not find work with money to live and resources to find a job. and if they do find a job, they still recieve money to support them while they earn their first few paychecks. often times youll get a job and have no money for transportation to and from the job and or food to sustain you. making it impossible to do the job you were hired to do

So a small amount of money to make them go to job fairs seems fair to me.

Most who lose their jobs are in almost immediate crisis. Plus job prospects go down as time goes by and over a year off leads to permanent loss of job status.  Terrible plan.

Yes, they should!! If government use the commodities we can have a better life. Everyone would get a chance! The money is not that much that they can live their whole life with that amount, I said yes because if they would be given some money they will find job for them so that can live better life and if they would not be given some money then they will choose some other easier way to earn money that is - they will start stealing and they will start doing different types of crimes to earn more and more money,
The plan motivates people to work.

It is acceptable to give the people funds so they can provide for their family. The job fairs would be helpful in encouraging them to get jobs. The people would run into problems if they can't find a job in that time period though.
People should not be paid by the government if they have a job. The money has to come from somewhere and that somewhere would be taxes.

This is great it does a couple of things. It motivates individuals to look for a job and compensate them while they are doing so. I would support this as it helps people while they are out of work and helps them with expenses.
its fair to compensate the employees whether or not they're working

The congress is providing financial support for citizens who are unemployed as well as providing job fairs for those who are unemployed. It is fair because their is a financial incentive for attending the job fairs.

I think it provides a universal income while also incentivizes work because they will be getting even more money rather than losing the $500 if they get a job.

it is not right to give people money for being out of work. If they are paid, what incentive do thet have to find work. On the other hand, some who are trying to find work , but can't do so deaserve to be given some money so they can pay bills. There is no easy answer to this
they will be receiving 500.00 even though they may find work.
It seems like the government is doing what they can to help support their citizens in finding employment.
because congress providing jobs to the people who are not able to find any jobs. It is a good idea.

I think that when you are out of work you can be depressed and feel like you are a failure.  It makes it hard to be motivated to look for work after several job turn downs.  This way you get a bit more motivation as the sooner you find work, you still get the $500 if any of the 6 months is left, helping to get caught up on bills.  This positive motivation will show when you are at job interviews and may give the extra confidence needed to get hired.
I choose this option because, in order to obtain benefits to better your self you should have to try to better yourself by lookingndir a job to get off of assistance
I feel that offering money for unemployment will not necessarily encourage citizens to find jobs.
This will give incentive for people to find a job. People will go to job fairs and be more likely to find work.

It's a good idea to help those that need work to find work. However, many of them might just take the $500 and not really try to find a job. Even if they show up at the fair, they might only do it for the check

This is kind of like the program that North Carolina runs in which anyone receiving unemployment benefits must be able to verify that they are actively looking for work by documenting the job searches they were doing as well as attend classes.

I have not heard of this idea before, so I would need to think about it for a while to come to a complete decision.  However, my initial thoughts are that it seems fairly appropriate.  I don't like giving people money not to work, but I see how continuing the payments might encourage people to look for a job if they didn't worry about losing that stipend right away.  It might help people cover gas costs or work clothing costs while waiting for their initial paychecks to come through.
This would be very helpful and encouraging for those unable to find work.  It sounds very fair for the congress to do this.

It will help the citizens recuperate money they lost while out of work and not discourage them in  finding a job. If the money stopped while they did have a job this could discourage some from finding a job.
I always think it's good to provide people with a bit to get them back on their feet.
It is helpful but not the best way. Attending job fairs doesn't do anything unless they are qualified for the jobs.

It is good for the government to try to help those workers who are looking for jobs. The government is helping them with their income and helping them find jobs. Because finding a decent jobs are difficult these days to support yourself, especially if you get laid off.I think this idea would be ok is enough to pay some bills etc.
I support a universal basic income. I would feel better if there were no strings attached but something is better than nothing.

It's kind hearted but promotes the wrong reward.  If someone finds a job in the first month, they're essentially getting $2500 for free.  It would be better to give the stipend out earlier and cut it off once the person is able to sustain themselves.

People need a hand up when they've been unemployed for a significant amount of time.  It's hard to climb up when everything is pushing you down.  I feel like it is the government's job to help it's citizens when the chips are down.
If someone has been attending job fairs for 12 months and actively looking for work, then they probably need the help that $500 a month will give them.

I think the requirements are fair and would make a big impact on citizens find employment. Twelve months is a long time to be unemployed and it proves the citizen is in need. I feel that providing assistance to the unemployed is very important; life overall can be very difficult for those who have been out of work for more than a year and I think that stipulating that the benefits are attached to monthly job events is fair. I don't think it is fair to reward people for not working.
Unemployment assistance can help the unemployed find work. If they have the means to do so, they are likely to pursue jobs.
it seems like a good use of donated funds
Those in the worst poverty need the most help. It's appropriate to provide for basic housing needs.
It is an excellent option to improve the living conditions of people with fewer resources
He is doing a good thing by providing the people in need with a good living condition.
I feel like it is a nice thing to try and help lower income people. A roof is a very nice thing.

it's like the old saying goes, "teach a man to fish and you feed him for a life time." By teaching someone a trade you are setting them up to be successful. It's also appropriate to teach someone rather than just giving them hand outs.
if he cares charity he should help equal
I am not convinced about any option.

I think it is very appropriate to give each person training in a trade of their choice because this way they will learn a skill which they will never forget or lose and they can use those skills to earn a living.

It's a good gesture, but I'm not really sure what it does in terms of helping people in poverty per se.  Maybe in that it helps people who need roofs to not have to foot the bill for that? But otherwise I'm not really seeing it.  But it's also not bad.

I think the director's decision is very well intentioned, and will hopefully help a lot of people. There may be easier ways to have the same positive impact on the same number of people.
His thoughts are in the right place and it would be a big benefit. But even though the donations were more than he thought how will he be able to help everyone. Roofs can be quite expencive.

Though the gesture of a strong roof is nice, I don't see how it helps lift a community out of poverty. The money should have been spent on teaching skills or improving education for the local population.

I believe that a sturdy roof pays "forward dividends" such as better health and better state of mind so I support the director making that decision.  I think that the director is using the money in a way that returns the greatest amount of benefits per the investment.
Having a sturdy roof can help combat disease. It is less likely bacteria will form if rain can be kept out of lodgings.

Perhaps he could have given people below a certain income level a more self-sustaining way to survive better, such as teaching them how to produce food. Having a roof over one's head is pretty basic for human beings to exist, so I feel it is somewhat appropriate, and a good starting point to help people.
Other than income level,. there should be other qualifications they evaluate for such as resources.  This sort of decision should be decided by a board, not one leader unilaterally.
There is nothing inappropriate about giving a roof to someone at a certain income level that can't afford one.

Maybe not everyone needs a sturdy roof. Maybe they need food instead. I don't think it's appropriate to assume what people need.

We don't know enough about the conditions or needs of the people living there. Maybe some of the most hungry already have a good roof and need food instead. Maybe more people are homeless and don't have a roof. The thought is nice, but we really need more information to decide if this is appropriate or the best use of these donations. What were the donors expecting to be done with their donations? We just don't know.
Because people that are trying hard but can not afford a decent roof should be getting help
Helping low income people to have a home that keeps them safe from the elements is one way to begin.  Having a roof over your head is essential in being able to provide for the family
Not all will want or need it, if they need it great but if their roof is fine, it's a waste of donations to do a new roof.
I think the director was trying to do a good thing and needed to find a fair way for people to qualify.
Shelter is a basic need that is often not met. When individuals are not able to meet their basic needs, they cannot work their way out of poverty
I think people the people can use the money differently like attending educational classes to get a better job.
Perhaps they don't need a new roof? What if they rent and don't own? Are they still able to receive services?
Seems like a nice thing to do. Most people below a certain income level probably need the help

A good roof is important to keep out diseases from a wide array of vectors like molds or even vermin that either eat the rotting roof or get in through the rotten roof. Another idea would be helping birth control availability and education.

Surely people need good roofs, and if this charity wants to provide them, then that is a good use of the charity's funds. However, I would think people in poverty might benefit more from other services like vocational training. This would provide them with skills to get better paying jobs and then they can take care of the roofs themselves.
A roof is a necessity and the adults probably have children so everyone will benefit. I think its its a good cause.

People in extreme poverty need access to food and clean water over a sturdy roof over their heads. It's not a bad suggestion, but not necessarily the highest on the priority list when it comes to essentials.

He used the money to give something to poor people that they need. The lower income people presumably had a greater need.
That sounds like a reasonable way to help people in poverty - give them shelter.  There are alternatives, of course, food, safety, education, but shelter is right up there.

Just because you have a sturdy roof doesn't mean it will help you with your poverty level.

I love people who want to help and I personally donate whenever I can. I think the director did the right thing.
Probably not one of the biggest concerns of low-income people. Also unlikely they own a home and are responsible for care of their roof. Better to respond to the direct needs of individual families.

I think that it is a great idea to get a sturdy roof because those people otherwise would either have a really leaky roof or it could blow off all together

The director's decision involves research with human subjects that doesn't obtain informed consent and therefore is inappropriate. (This study also didn't obtain informed consent, by the way.) However, I chose "Somewhat inappropriate" instead of "Very inappropriate" because the manipulation the director wants to use doesn't pose any additional risks to the patients other than the risks they will already be facing from the procedure. Instead, the manipulation only involves potential benefits (assuming that currently the procedure is done without any reminders of the safety steps -- incidentally, it would be a more controlled study if one group were treated exactly according to the status quo, i.e. no safety reminders, instead of both groups involving an experimental manipulation).
The director thinks that these posters might help doctors remember all of the safety steps they were trained to take during the procedure.
If the hospital director thinks the ID badge provides better precautions, then he/she should require that instead of having a control group with the precautions hanging on the wall.
This in not invasive in any way.  The list could potentially help a doctor to remember all the steps and thus prevent an infection from happening.

I feel it is somewhat appropriate, depending upon how frequently the doctor performs this procedure.  If it is important to remember (and perform) all of the steps, then it is appropriate to have them clearly listed (and have that list accessible.)  Although some patients might feel uneasy if their doctor is referencing a "cheat sheet" on their badge, I believe most would prefer that safety (infection prevention) is maximized.
helps remember
I would think a doctor should know the steps instead of having to check his/her badge or a poster.

The individual teacher's importance, or interest, in the incentive presented to them is what will drive their work value. If a teacher is assigned to the vacation days group, for example, but as an individual finds the bonus a higher incentive then they will not be working as hard for their designated incentive. In addition, someone may find the incentive of great personal interest. They may want to have the vacation days, and work hard towards that goal. To then have the incentive changed at the end of the Superintendent's experiment does not take into account what that individual worked for.

Both options are something I believe the teachers would like. Perhaps it would be better to giver the teachers the options between the two but I don't see anything wrong with what has been done as an experiment for which the teachers might enjoy more.

I think it sounds like a great way to decide how best to increase teacher performance. Happy teachers will work harder and be more positive with the children, so by keeping them happy, the student's scores and performance will likely go up as well. The superintendent is testing which variable results in the most improvement. It is a somewhat fair way to make that decision. I imagine that such a decision would require more than a year of testing. However, it is a good start.

I believe that it is great to test out these two options to see which improves the teachers and the student outcomes. While I admire his dedication towards scientifically determining and outcome, this seems wrong on a number of reasons. First of all, it is not said whether the teachers consented to this experiment. Secondly, how has he decided that these two things are the best way to make teachers happier? Lastly, they may not be a one size fits all model as we don't know what each individual teacher would value more.

While this may be effective and each teacher is being compensated, I do think it would be a better idea to just ask what teachers would prefer and what they believe would help them to be more effective teachers.

I do feel that there is a distinct advantage to knowing everything regarding your own DNA, the good, the bad and the ugly. For instance, if you know that you are likely to contract ALS, you have the advantage of preparing, of not passing on the genes, of living life in a shorter time, completing your bucket list. Withholding information from people may seem kind but it is not. I have heard the argument that most people receiving unhappy information regarding their genetic destiny cannot "handle the truth", but this is a specious argument. Let people decide for themselves if they want the full report or if they would rather only know the non-devastating information. This is the right thing to do.  Give people their own choice over the knowledge contained in their own DNA.

If the participant has the OPTION to have these additional screenings performed, there is nothing inappropriate about it. However, the key to this is how the data is gathered and stored. Whether or not the information is viewed by the participant, if the data is held in any way that can later be acquired by any agency (by change of law, etc.) with identification of the participant, a threat against the privacy of the participant can easily be predicted and would be highly inappropriate. Knowledge to benefit a participant is great, but only if it can be guaranteed to be permanently private.

Workers interested in healthcare can benefit from the short training period required to work. Remote populations benefit from increased access to care. Many health issues affecting impoverished areas are easily treatable and, therefore, managable by a less experienced worker. The risk would be to first line workers coming in direct contact with sickness; superstitious or skeptical patients. The risk would also be to patients who have more serious issues that could be misdiagnosed or poorly treated due to worker inexperience. Overall, however, I think congress's intentions are good.

In addition to the suggestion of describing the benefits of becoming a Health Assistant, the Congress would should also emphasize the first-line medical help. This would, in my opinion, be something that would catch the eye on a poster or similar handout.

This idea eases the burden on Public Health Systems by huge numbers of those seeking services at free or reduced cost. This idea also creates a much easier level of care for the aging, mentally ill and substance abuse patients who normally would be cast out of the better and more expensive private systems.

First, I am concerned about the reliability of that information.  Does the data collection and analyses meet medical standards?  I recall reading an article about identical triplet women from Minnesota who did the DNA ancestry testing and received differing results.  This implies the quality of testing is probably best described "as for entertainment use only".If the information is provided solely to the person for their sole use and disclosure, then I find that use somewhat acceptable.  I would strongly advise that person to confirm this information with redundant testing from a qualified medical practitioner in which the testing meets medical standards.My concern is if that information enters the public domain, either by hacking or by sale to others.  Could that information then be misused?  We have had to many breaches of major systems (Equifax, etc.).   Could someone be bombarded with unsolicited emails / phishing / spam because the hacked / sold information indicates someone has a medical condition?  Could a person be denied a financial transaction (e.g. loan), if the information indicates a high risk of an early death?  If a third party (e.g. lender) uses this information, are they required to disclose it?  Does the victim (e.g. the prospective borrower) then need to fight it in court or get official medical testing to prove / disprove.

A common complaint of welfare and "food stamps" recipients is that getting a job often reduces or eliminates those aid payments to the point that they are now making even less money than before (due to being paid minimum wage or less than minimum, for example waiting tables). This tends to discourage such people from seeking employment because their budget becomes even tighter than before.I believe that the gov't's decision to continue paying their citizens even after they've gotten a job would greatly reduce the stress of their citizens living in poverty and make it easier for them to transition to the workforce without being distracted by the prospect of poorer wages.
